body: PARIS has its baguettes and Dublin its soda bread. San Francisco trades heavily in sourdough, while New Orleans greets each morning with beignets. It wouldn't be Philadelphia without soft pretzels and it couldn't be Bonn without pumpernickel. But no city, perhaps in the history of the world, is so closely identified with a breadstuff as New York is
title: Was Life Better When Bagels Were Smaller?

body: TEN years ago, when Karen Brenner first moved to Park Slope, she settled in a rented one-bedroom floor-through on Third Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. In 2001 she moved again. She bought a two-bedroom apartment in a newly built 36-unit condominium called Park Slope Estates on Second Street between Fifth and Fourth Avenues. To outsiders
title: Rezoning, and Redefining, Park Slope

body: After two days of fame, the gigantic, nameless snowstorm that had dominated life in the Northeast churned to oblivion in the North Atlantic yesterday as armies of plows cleared highways, airports limped back toward normal schedules and the residents of a dozen states began to dig out of mountainous drifts. The storm, the biggest on record for early
title: After Snowstorm's Raging Glory, Now Comes the Great Slush Shove

body: The first major snowstorm of the season -- a powerful one-two punch that pummeled the East Coast and promised another wallop of snow and freezing temperatures -- snarled traffic yesterday and left travelers stranded at airports. The storm covered Central Park with eight inches of snow yesterday, less than it left behind elsewhere as it crawled up
title: New York Slips, Slides and Stalls In Early Storm

body: Robin Strober hates hardware stores. ''They bore me,'' she said the other day, ''and I don't have any use for them.'' So why she ventured into a True Value Hardware in Brooklyn three years ago is really anyone's guess. Call it artistic intervention. ''I don't really know why I was in there, maybe buying nails or something, and I drifted over to the
title: The Name Game

body: A picture caption on Monday about Windsor Terrace, a Brooklyn neighborhood where many residents have ties to the military, misidentified the street shown. The homes flying the American flag were on Windsor Place between 10th and 11th Avenues -- not on 16th Street, a block away.
title: Corrections

body: It is the kind of neighborhood where the faded row houses fly the American flag and the leafless trees spaced along the sidewalk have stone markers with the names of soldiers who fell in America's wars. Boys -- and increasingly girls -- may spend their childhoods in scout troops, grow up to become police officers or firefighters and in between
title: A NATION AT WAR: NEIGHBORHOOD; In Brooklyn, the Soldiers Are Family and Friends
